docs.lead_paragraph: Americans of both sexes are living longer, but the gap between life expectancy of men and women is actually widening, a recent conference of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists was told. Some 3,500 members of the organization of physicians who have completed postgraduate training in the specialty spent six days in San Francisco learning about advances in hormone therapy for the problems of menopause, new options for infertile couples and the effect of employment, income and other socioeconomic factors on women's health. ''The gap in longevity between men and women is widening,'' said Dr. Robert N. Butler, chairman of the department of geriatrics of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York City. ''The life expectancy of women is now 78 years, compared with 70 years for men. In 1900, the life expectancy of women was 48 and for men 46.''

headline.main: DIFFERENCES IN LIFE EXPECTANCY WIDENS BETWEEN THE SEXES

docs.snippet: Americans of both sexes are living longer, but the gap between life expectancy of men and women is actually widening, a recent conference of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists was told.    Some 3,500 members of the organization...
